Description: Cast model of situla in copper alloy; slender, bag-shaped with pronounced, pointed base; two opposite vertical suspension rings welded at mouth, handle missing; undecorated; corroded and slightly encrusted with corroded substance in holes of suspension rings.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by McLean Museum and Art Gallery, Greenock. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Situlae were used for libation of water or milk (Junker 1913, 10). This specimen, however, is just a model and not an actual piece of temple equipment. Situlae in metal, decorated or not, are common votive objects of the Late and Ptolemaic Period. They were massively produced ex-votos that visiting pilgrims dedicated in temples and shrines (see the chapter on situlae in Green 1987, 66-115). At least seven specimens were collected from Naukratis early excavations. Green, C. I. 1987, The Temple furniture from the Sacred Animal Necropolis at North Saqqâra 1964-1976 (Egypt Exploration Society Memoirs 53), London, 66-115. Junker, H. 1913, Das Gotterdekret über das Abaton, Vienna.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MC.03) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: McLean Museum & Art Gallery
